questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 presents at 30 weeks of gestation with her USG scan, showing a single deepest vertical pocket of 10cm. On examination, her fundal height was greater than the period of gestation. The uterus felt tense, and there was difficulty palpating fetal parts. Fetal heart sounds were normal but auscultated with difficulty. Which among the following could be likely etiologies for this presentation?
  1. Red cell alloimmunization
  2. Maternal pre-eclampsia
  3. Posterior urethral valve
  4. Micrognathia
  5. Esophageal atresia
questions.solution:
An ultrasonography report showing a single vertical pocket of >8cm, with a fundal height greater than the period of gestation indicates polyhydramnios, causes of which may be red cell alloimmunization, micrognathia, and esophageal atresia. (1, 4, and 5)

Polyhydramnios or hydramnios refers to abnormally increased amniotic fluid volume. It is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • The single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8 cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options: Maternal preeclampsia and posterior urethral valve are causes of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed when AFI is less than 5 cm or a single deepest pocket of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: As an intern, you see the obstetric index on the file of one of the patients admitted to your unit. The obstetric index is G2P1 and she is in her 35th week of pregnancy. All of the following can be possible case scenarios in this aspect, except ______.

choices.text: She had twins in her previous pregancy and this is her second pregnancy.
She has one living child and this is her second pregnancy
After a spontaneous miscarriage at 12 weeks, this is her second pregnancy
After a stillbirth, this is her second pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option C is the answer. If this is her second pregnancy after a spontaneous miscarriage at 12 weeks, her obstetric index would be G2P0, as her first pregnancy did not cross the period of viability (28 weeks).

The term gravida refers to a woman who currently is pregnant or has been in the past, irrespective of the pregnancy outcome. As part of the obstetric index, it refers to the number of times she has been pregnant, irrespective of whether it crossed the period of viability. A current pregnancy, if any, is included in this count.

With her first pregnancy, she is a primi­ gravida, and with successive pregnancies, a multigravida. Nulligravida is a woman who currently is not pregnant and has never been pregnant.

Parity is determined by the number of pregnancies reaching a period of viability. It is not increased to a higher number if multiples (twins/triplets) are delivered in a given pregnancy and still counts as 'one birth'. Moreover, stillbirth does not lower this number. Para indicates the number of viable births. A current pregnancy, if any, is not included in this count.

Nullipara refers to a woman who has never completed a pregnancy beyond 28 weeks gestation. She may never have been preg­nant or may have had a spontaneous or elective abortion(s) or an ectopic pregnancy.

Primipara refers to a woman who has delivered a baby only once- alive or dead, with a gestation period of 28 or more weeks.

Both parity and gravida refer to the pregnancy and not the fetuses.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following are likely to be seen physiologically?

choices.text: Increase in 1,2, and 7; no change in 3, 5 and 6
Increase in 1, 2 and 4; no change in 3, 5 and 7
Increase in 1 and 7; no change in 2 and 4
Increase in 3, 5 and 6; no change in 1 and 2

questions.solution:
Tidal volume and inspiratory capacity (1 and 7) increase physiologically during pregnancy, while inspiratory reserve volume and vital capacity (2 and 4) remain unchanged.

Changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: You were asked to assess a 36-year-old primigravid woman in her 40th week of gestation just before labor was induced. Which of the following are favorable factors for successful induction of labor in this woman?
questions.solution:
A body mass index of < 30 kg/m2 favors successful induction of labor.

Favorable factors for induction of labor include:

  • Young age
  • Mul­tiparity
  • Body mass index (BMI) < 30
  • Favorable cervix; Bishops score ≥ 9. A score of < or = 6 is considered unfavorable
  • Estimated fetal birthweight < 3.5kg
  • Positive oxytocin sensitivity test (indicates the sensitivity of the uterus)
  • Period of gestation closer to term or post-term
  • Presence of fetal fibronectin in vaginal swab (> 50 ng/mL) 

Note:

  • As per Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, a Bishop's score ≥9 indicates a high likelihood for successful induction of labor.
  • As per NICE guidelines, a Bishop's score ≥8 indicates that the cervix is ripe, favorable, a high chance of spontaneous delivery or response to induction.
  • As per FOGSI guidelines, the cervix is considered favorable if Bishop's score is > 6.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida who conceived dichorionic diamniotic twins presented at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the first twin was found to be in cephalic presentation and the second twin in breech presentation. All of the following can be undertaken for delivery except?

choices.text: Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, breech extraction of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, internal podalic version of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, external cephalic version and delivery of 2nd twin

questions.solution:
All of the above-mentioned measures can be undertaken in this case except vaginal delivery of 1st twin and internal podalic version of 2nd twin.

The internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure in which the baby is turned inside the uterus such that the feet present through the cervix. Upward pressure is applied by the abdominal hand on the head while downward traction is exerted on the feet and the baby is then delivered by breech extraction. It is indicated when the second twin is in a transverse lie, not breech. This procedure is always done under general or epidural anesthesia.

When the first twin is cephalic and the second is non-cephalic, the following methods can be used:

  • Breech extraction of the second twin (Option A)
  • C-section of both twins (Option C)
  • An external cephalic version of the second twin (Option D)
  • Rarely, cesarean section of the second twin following vaginal delivery of the first

The ACOG recommends termination of pregnancy at 38 weeks of pregnancy in dichorionic gestations. Cesarean section is preferred when the first twin is in a breech position. An attempted vaginal delivery can cause locking of the fetuses, trapping of the fetal head above the cervix, and umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presented to casualty with sudden onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, she was tachycardic, her blood pressure was normal, and there were no signs of shock. The uterus was tender and the fetal heart rate was markedly elevated. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal pain, maternal tachycardia, a tender uterus with vaginal bleeding, and fetal distress point to a diagnosis of abruptio placentae, for which primiparity is not a risk factor. The risk of developing abruption increases with increasing parity (primiparity is not a risk factor).

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery. It is initiated by hemorrhage into the decidua basalis. Consequently, a decidual hematoma forms and expands, causing the placenta to get separated and compressed.

The bleeding between the membranes and uterus escapes through the cervix leading to external hemorrhage. Less often, the blood gets retained between the detached placenta and the uterus, leading to concealed hemorrhage.

Risk factors for placental abruption:

  • Prior abruption
  • Increased age and parity 
  • Cocaine use, Cigarette smoking (Option A)
  • Preterm prematurely ruptured membrane (Option B)
  • Preeclampsia and chronic hypertension (Option D)
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Low birth weight
  • Hydramnios
  • Trauma
  • Uterine leiomyoma - especially if located near the mucosal surface behind the placental implantation site
  • Single umbilical artery

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urinary pregnancy test presented with mild pain abdomen and slight bleeding per vaginum for 5 days. She was diagnosed with cervical pregnancy. Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the labor room. You were asked to perform a vaginal examination and calculate the modified Bishop's score. Which among the following parameter is not used in this score?
questions.solution:
Cervical effacement % is not used in the calculation of the modified Bishop score. It has been replaced with cervical length.

The Bishop score is a cervical scoring system used to assess the induction of labor. The parameters calculated include:

  • Cervical length (effacement in the original score): The length of the cer­vical canal reflects the degree of cervical effacement
  • Cervical position: It refers to the relation­ship of the cervical os to the fetal head.
    • It can be posterior, mid-position, or anterior.
  • Cervical dilatation: It is determined by estimating the average diameter of the cervical opening. The cervix is said to be fully dilated at 10 cm.
  • Consistency of the cervix: Maybe soft, firm, or inter­mediate between these two.
  • Station of the head: It refers to the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal concerning the ischial spines. Each fifth represents 1 cm above or below the spines.
    • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines, the designation is -5,
      -4, -3, -2, -1, 0 stations till the ischial spines.
    • Past the ischial spines, it is +1, +2, +3, +4, and +5 sta­tions to delivery.
    • Station +5 cm indicates that the fetal head is visible at the introitus.

These parameters are noted while doing a vaginal examination. The maximum attainable score is 13. A Bishops score >=9 indicates a high likelihood for successful induction of labor. A score <=6 is considered unfavorable.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A paramedic in the ambulance is examining a G2P1 lady, who is in labor. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. However, the cord was found to be prolapsed outside the vulva. Which of the following first aid measures should not be done by the ambulance staff?

choices.text: Put her in exaggerated Sim's position
Adjust stretcher for reverse Trendelenburg position
Place 2 fingers in the vagina and elevate the presenting part

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests cord prolapse, and the patient should be put in a Trendelenburg position (not reverse Trendelenburg). This relieves cord compression by elevating the presenting part, till definitive management can be undertaken.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section. Till then, the following first aid measures can be carried out:

  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
  • Stop oxytocin, if ongoing
  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina. (Option D)
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position (Option A), or knee-chest position
  • Vagos method (Option B): A Foley catheter is placed, and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
  • Funic reduction: Gentle replacement of the umbilical cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

Given below are the images of Trendelenburg's position, exaggerated Sim’s position, and knee-chest position, respectively:

questions.text:
A primigravid mother gave birth to a baby having the karyotype shown in the image below. She mentions that a screening test was done in her 16th week of pregnancy, which indicated the possibility of an abnormality in the fetus. Which of the following parameters would not have been measured as part of the screening test?

MSAFP- Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin

PAPPA- Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is not measured in the second trimester (16th week) screening tests. It is included in the combined 1st-trimester screening.

The karyotype in the picture indicates Edward's syndrome or Trisomy 18. Maternal serum MSAFP, beta hCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A
Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. Which among the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day of postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by a placental polyp.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

It is treated with oxytocin, methyler­gonovine, or a prostaglandin analog if the patient is stable and sonography reveals an empty uterine cavity. Antimicrobials are given if a uterine infection is suspected. Gentle suction curettage can be done if large clots are seen in the uter­ine cavity on sonography, or if bleeding persists after medical management.

Other options: 

Option A: Multiparity can lead to inadequate retraction and frequently adherent placenta and cause primary PPH.

Option B: Perineal lacerations and an atonic uterus are causes of primary PPH. 

Option C: Atonic uterus is one of the causes of primary PPH.

questions.text: While examining a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea who presented with vomiting and vaginal bleeding, you find that the cervical os is open and that the uterus is 16 weeks in size. The patient also has abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG (>1 lakh mIU/mL). Which of the following is likely to be seen on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, and large-for-date uterus, with abnormally elevated HCG levels points towards a diagnosis of molar pregnancy, and a snowstorm appearance is characteristically seen on ultrasound in such cases. It is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

A molar pregnancy occurs due to the fusion of one sperm with an empty ovum or the fusion of 2 sperms simultaneously with an ovum. It may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG. 

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

  • Complete moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes. In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46,XX karyotype. In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46,XX, or 46,XY.
  • Partial moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms. The karyotype is usually triploid (69,XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92,XXXY). It is associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but is not associated with choriocarcinoma.

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable. 

The given images show the development of hydatiform mole and snowstorm appearance on USG, respectively:

 

Other options:

Option A: Necklace appearance on ultrasound is seen in polycystic ovary disease. Multiple cysts (12 or more) of 2–9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary, giving it this appearance. It is shown in the image below:


Option B: Ring-of-fire appearance is seen on color Doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text:
Which of the following parameters are included in the modified Biophysical profile score?
  1. Oxytocin challenge test
  2. Contraction stress test
  3. Amniotic fluid index
  4. Vibroacoustic nonstress test
  5. Amniotic fluid volume
questions.solution:
Vibroacoustic nonstress test/Nonstress test (NST) and Amniotic fluid index (AFI) (options 3 and 4) are included in the modified biophysical score.

Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score provides a means of accessing fetal health. Involves the measurement of the following: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • B-Breathing 
  • A-Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
  • T-Tone of fetus
  • M-Movements of fetus
  • N-Non Stress Test (NST)

Normal score: >=8 (with normal AFV). The maximum score is 10.

Abnormal scores:

  • 8/10 with decreased AFV: suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia
  • 6/10: Possible fetal asphyxia
  • 4/10: Probable fetal asphyxia
  • 0-2/10: Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Maternal sedatives and narcotics can significantly lower the score.

The biophysical profile was modified to includes two parameters- the biweekly vibroacoustic nonstress test or Nonstress test and the AFI. 

The nonstress test describes fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements, using a Doppler to detect fetal heart rate acceleration. Fetal movements are recorded as perceived by the mother. Acoustic stimula­tion nonstress test is one in which a loud external sound is used to startle the fetus and provoke heart rate accelerations.

  • Normal modified BPP: Reactive nonstress test with AFI>5cm
  • Abnormal modified BPP: nonreactive nonstress test or AFI <5 cm 

Oxytocin challenge test (Contraction stress test): The fetal heart rate and uterine contrac­tions are recorded simultaneously with an external monitor. If at least three spontaneous contractions of 40 seconds or longer are present in 10 minutes, uterine stimulation is not required. If required, it can be done with iv oxytocin or nipple stimulation.

A positive test(abnormal) is uniform repetitive late fetal heart rate decelerations, which could indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. A negative test would show no late or significant variable decelerations.

The nonstress test is a test of fetal condition, while the contraction stress test is a test of uteroplacental function.

Contraindications of contraction stress testing:

  • Compromised fetus
  • Previous history of cesarean section
  • Complications likely to produce preterm labor
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Multiple pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following substances cannot cross the placental barrier?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ascorbic acid, iron, and IgG can cross the placenta and parathormone does not cross the placenta.

The placental membrane is a partition separating the maternal and fetal portions of the placenta. It acts as a protective barrier for the fetus and selectively allows the passage of nutrients to the fetus. Substances with a molecular weight of more than 500 daltons are not allowed to pass through the barrier. Substances crossing the placenta from the maternal to fetal blood first traverse the syncytiotrophoblast, the cytotropho­blast layer, the villous stroma, and finally, the fetal capillary wall. 

The syncytiotrophoblast actively or passively adjusts the amount and rate of substance transfer to the fetus. The fetal-facing basal cell membrane is the site of transfer to the intra-villous space.

Substances that can cross the placenta are as follows:

Substances 

Mechanism

Molecular mass less than 500 DA 

Eg: oxygen, carbon dioxide, water, most electrolytes, and anesthetic gases

Simple diffusion

 

Glucose

Facilitated diffusion with GLUT-1 and GLUT-3

Insulin, steroid hormones, and thyroid hormones 

Can cross the placenta but very slowly

Immunoglobulin G (molecular weight 160,000 Da )

 Endocytosis and trophoblast Fc receptors 

Iron (unidirectional from mother to fetus), Iodide, Calcium, Phosphorous

Carrier-mediated active transport

Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)

Carrier-mediated active transport

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labor. After delivery of the head, a positive turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following maneuvres cannot be used for the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The case of gestational diabetes with a positive turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Pinard's maneuver is not used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • Mc.Roberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus. (shown below)

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: The ultrasonogram image shows the diameter of the fetal head which is taken as a reference for engagement. Which diameter does this refer to?
questions.solution:
The fetal head is said to be engaged when the biparietal diameter (shown in the image) passes through the pelvic brim. It is the greatest transverse diameter in an occiput presentation.

In many multiparas and some nulliparas, the fetal head is freely movable above the pelvic inlet at the onset of labor. This is referred to as floating. 

The biparietal diameter also reflects the gestational age in the second trimester, with a variation of 7-10 days. It is measured perpendicular to the midline falx, at the level of the thalami and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP) in the transthalamic view.

 

The engaging anteroposterior diameters of various presentations are:

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) The attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion Vertex
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion Vertex
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension Brow
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension Face

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with amenorrhea for the past 4 months. On performing USG, you notice the presence of twin gestation, with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below. When will the division of the inner cell mass occur in this type of twin gestation?
questions.solution:
The given USG image depicts the T sign, which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation, for which division of the inner cell mass occurs at 4–8 days. 

Time of division Type of twin gestation
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4–8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or at the beginning of the second trimester. In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the first trimester.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A woman at her 31st week of gestation presented to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain. The on-duty clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor and asks you to arrange and collect a sample to check for fetal fibronectin. From where is the sample taken?
questions.solution:
Fetal fibronectin in cervicovaginal secretions is used as a marker for impending preterm labor before membrane rupture.

Qualitative and quantitative fetal fibronectin levels are measured using ELISA, and levels >50 ng/mL is considered positive.

Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amnionic fluid, however, sample contamination by amnionic fluid and mater­nal blood should be avoided.

It aids in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in the maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua. It reflects stromal remodeling of the cervix before labor.

Preterm labor (PTL) refers to the onset of labor before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

questions.text: A multigravida woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, blood pressure 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria - 3+. She was given a loading dose of 14g MgSO4, followed by 5g intramuscularly every 4 hours in the alternate buttocks. Which regimen is being followed here?
questions.solution:
A 33 Weeks multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, blood pressure of 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria -3+ which indicates severe preeclampsia. The administration of MgSO4 is being given here is by the Pritchard regimen.

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 mL/h
  • Respiratory rate > 12/minute

It is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery whichever is later.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Used to deliver the after coming head in breech
  2. Used in the correction of asynclitism of the head
  3. Exclusively outlet forceps
  4. Delivers head in mento-posterior position
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C.

Image 1: Kielland forceps: It is used as a rotation forceps. It is a long and almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has a sliding lock that facilitates the correction of asynclitism of the head. For forceps rotations from an OP to OA position, deep transverse arrest, unrotated vertex or face presentations, the Kielland forceps are preferred since their pelvic curve is less pronounced.  

Image 2: Pipers forceps: have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Image 3: Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • the fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • the fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • the sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other forceps used in obstetrics include:

  • Low or mid-cavity forceps, e.g. Neville Barnes, Andersons, Simpsons. They are used when:

    • the fetal head is one-fifth palpable per abdomen
    • the leading point of the skull is above  +2 cm but not above the ischial spines
    • rotation of 45° or less.

Mento-posterior position: Forceps should not be applied because vaginal delivery is impossible unless the fetus is very small. 

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with lower abdominal pain at 36 weeks of gestation and assumes it to be labor pain. Which of the following statements is incorrect about false labor pain?

choices.text: More commonly experienced by primigravidae than multigravidae
It is associated with the formation of a bag of waters
Pain is relieved by enema and sedation

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about false labor pain is that it is associated with the formation of a bag of waters. True labor pains are associated with the formation of the bag of waters. 

False labor pain is characterized by dull, irregular, and unpredictable pain confined to the lower abdomen and groin. It is not associated with the hardening of the uterus or bag of waters formation and does not cause cervical dilation. Usually, it is relieved with enema or sedatives. It is also known as Braxton Hicks contractions.

It is more common in primigravidae than in parous women and usually appears 1 or 2 weeks prior to the onset of true labor pain in primigravidae and a few days prior in multiparae. 

True labor pain is characterized by pain in the lower abdomen and back, radiating to the thighs. It occurs due to painful uterine contractions at regular intervals with increasing frequency, intensity and duration. It is associated with the show (cervical mucus plug with blood), progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix and descent of the presenting part. It is not relieved by enema or sedatives.

A bag of waters refers to the lower pole of the fetal membranes containing liquor amnii which bulges into the cervical canal below the presenting part. During uterine contraction, the bag becomes tense and convex due to the rise in intra-amniotic pressure and disappears completely after the contractions. This is almost a certain sign of the onset of true labor.

questions.text: The modified WHO partograph was presented to you during your labor room postings. Which of the following statements is incorrect about it?

choices.text: Action line is 4 hours left and parallel to the alert line
The slope of the alert line is 1cm/hour

questions.solution:
The action line is situated 4 hours to the right and parallels the alert line.

Partograph/Partogram is a composite graphical record of maternal and fetal data during labor, entered against time on a single sheet of paper. It has been recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) to monitor the progress of labor and identify and intervene in cases of abnormal labor.

Components of partograph:

  • Patient identification
  • Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 min
  • Pulse recorded every 30 min
  • Blood pressure and temperature recorded every 4 h
  • Uterine contractions recorded every 30 min
  • Oxytocin-dose and concentration
  • Urine analysis
  • Vaginal examination is done every 4 hours
  • State of membranes and color of the liquor
  • If the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, record BP every 30 minutes.

The first of the three partograms by WHO is the composite partograph. It includes a latent phase of 8 hours and an active phase starting at 3-cm cervical dilatation. It has an alert line with a slope at 1 cm/h and the action line 4 h to the right and parallel to the alert line. Descent of the fetal head, maternal condition, fetal condition, and medicines administered are also recorded.

WHO modified the partograph in 2000, excluding the latent phase, and the active phase commencing at 4-cm cervical dilatation. The other features remained the same. The reason was that prolonged latent was overdiagnosed with an increase in interventions. There was also difficulty reported in transferring the dilatation from latent phase to active phase.

The third modification included color-coding:

Left of the alert line Green Normal progress
Between alert and action lines Amber Greater vigilance
Right of the action line Red Dangerously slow progress

questions.text: A nursing mother in her third week postpartum presents with pain in her breast and difficulty breastfeeding. Examination reveals a warm, swollen, and tender breast, and is shown in the image below. Her temperature is 38.3 degrees and the WBC count is 13000/ cumm. Which of the following are not included in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red and swollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. Breastfeeding should not be stopped, and continued breastfeeding is advised.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus,  present in the infant's nose and throat. Predisposing factors to develop mastitis include fissures, abrasions, or cracks in the nipple.

Symptoms usually appear in the 3rd-4th week postpartum. The infection is usually unilateral with marked engorgement of the breast which may even progress into an abscess. There may be fever, chills, rigors, and tachycardia. Severe pain occurs and the breast becomes hard and red.

Management:

  • Breastfeeding should be continued. Often, vigorous expression of breast milk is a sufficient treatment. Pumping of the breasts relieves the engorgement and edema of the inflamed breast. The baby is encouraged to feed from the uninvolved breast first as it allows the let-down reflex to begin before moving to the tender breast.
  • Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers. Other beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins that are recommended include cloxacillin and flucloxacillin.
  • Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  • If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given.
  • If an abscess is formed, surgical drainage is done under general anesthesia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady with a known history of mitral stenosis presented with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Which of the following is not true about labor and delivery in this case?

choices.text: Oxytocin is used to control hemorrhage

questions.solution:
From the given options, the false statement about the management of mitral valve stenosis is option D. 

Epidural analgesia is safe in most heart diseases and is not contraindicated.

Management during labor in heart diseases like mitral stenosis: 

Vaginal delivery is preferred over cesarean, and induction of labor is safe. Induction can be done with vaginal PGE2.

First stage of labor:

  • Lateral semirecumbent position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural, combined epidural/spinal, or continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Fluids should not be infused at more than 75 mL/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage of labor:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anesthesia
  • Withhold IV ergometrine with the delivery of anterior shoulder

Third stage of labor:

  • Oxytocin by infusion

Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetric indications such as:

  • Dilated aortic root >4cm
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Warfarin within 2 weeks of delivery
  • Emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed for postpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.

Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).

It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.

questions.text: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy. 

Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp. 

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Loin pain
  • Vomiting
  • Right-sided renal angle tenderness

Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia.

Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.

questions.text: Mothers having any of the following conditions are advised not to breastfeed their infants, except _______

choices.text: A mother who is undergoing breast cancer treatment
A mother who has active tuberculosis
A mother who has hepatitis C infection
Mothers who do not control their alcohol use

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in mothers having a hepatitis C infection.

Maternal Hepatitis C is not a contraindication because breastfeeding has not shown to transmit the infection.

Contraindications of breastfeeding:

Do not Breastfeed

Do not give expressed breastmilk

Infant factors:

  • Classic galactosemia

Maternal factors:

  • Human T-cell lymphocyte virus (HTLV) infection
  • Ebola virus infection
  • PCP/cocaine abuse

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Do not give expressed breastmilk  (Temporarily)

Maternal factors:

  • Brucellosis
  • undergoing Diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals
  • Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Can give expressed breastmilk

Maternal factors:

  • Untreated, active Tuberculosis
  • active Varicella infection

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.

According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). 

Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:

Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects

Beta-adrenergic agonists:

  • Ritodrine
  • Terbutaline
  • Isoxsuprine

Headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDS

Fetal heart failure, intrauterine death

Neonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Nifedipine
  • Nicardipine
  • Verapamil
 Hypotension, headache, flushing, nausea -

Oxytocin antagonists:

  • Atosiban

(not approved for use in India)

 Nausea, vomiting, chest pain -
Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depression

COX inhibitors:

  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
 Heartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramnios Constriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth restriction

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails. Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postmaturity syndrome which can occur due to placental sulphatase deficiency.

Etiology of post-term pregnancy:

  • Wrong dates - inaccurate LMP (most common)
  • Heredity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Anencephaly
  • Placental sulphatase deficiency (leads to decreased estrogen synthesis)
  • Primipara/ elderly multipara

Features of postmaturity syndrome in a newborn:

  • Wrinkled, patchy, peeling skin, particularly prominent on the palms and soles
  • Long, thin body suggesting wasting
  • Long nails
  • Eyes open and unusually alert
  • Looks old and worried

Note: Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development of fetus.

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter that the obstetrician is measuring in the image below is _______.
questions.solution:
The AP diameter that the obstetrician is measuring is the diagonal conjugate.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet:

  • Diagonal conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. 
    • It measures 12 cm (4 ¾").
  • Obstetric conjugate:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis.
    • It measures 10 cm (4").
  • Anatomical/true conjugate/conjugate vera:
    • It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. 
    • It measures 11 cm.

The clinically diagonal conjugate is measured, and the obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.

questions.text: The final conditioning of the spermatozoa in the female reproductive tract takes place in the  _______.
questions.solution:
The final conditioning of the spermatozoa in the female reproductive tract is called capacitation and it occurs in the uterine tube.

It is a period of conditioning (adaptation of sperm in the female reproductive tract), which lasts approximately 7 hours.

Fertilization involves two steps: 

1) Capacitation 

  • Capacitation occurs in the uterine tube and involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the mucosal surface of the tube.
  • During capacitation, the glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.
  • Only capacitated sperms can pass through the corona cells and undergo the acrosomal reaction.

2) Acrosomal reaction 

  • It occurs after binding to zona pellucida, induced by zona proteins. 
  • This includes the release of enzymes required to penetrate the zona pellucida. 
  • Ca2+ plays an important role.

Phases can be divided as follows: 

  • Phase 1: Penetration of the corona radiata
  • Phase 2: Penetration of the zona pellucida
  • Phase 3: Fusion of the oocyte and sperm cell membranes

questions.text: On doing a per-vaginal examination of a woman in labor, you were able to palpate the mouth with hard alveolar margins, nose, malar eminence, and supraorbital ridges of the fetus. Which of the following would have been the engaging diameter for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter for the face presentation seen here is submentovertical diameter, which is about 11.5 cm.

In the given question the palpable parts in the per-vaginal examination of a multiparous woman are the mouth with hard alveolar margins, nose, malar eminence, supraorbital ridges, and mentum which indicates a face presentation.

Diameters of the fetal skull

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) Attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion  Vertex 
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion  Vertex 
Occupitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion  Vertex 
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension  Brow 
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension  Face 
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension  Face

questions.text: A P1A1 woman with a history of obstructed labor is being evaluated for a contracted pelvis. CT pelvis shows both sacral alae are absent. What is the type of pelvis seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the ala on both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones.

Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum.

Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either following tuberculosis or rickets.

Option D: In rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient who is a known case of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome comes with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days. She has also had an episode of seizure. Her BP and temperature were higher than normal. What of the following investigation can be used to diagnose her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis, which can be diagnosed by magnetic resonance venography.

It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilias or antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom associated with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focal deficits. Up to a third of patients have convulsions.

Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and is often associated with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.

Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous hemorrhage has occurred, but the venous sinus occlusion is readily visualized using magnetic resonance (MR) or CT venography.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy?
questions.solution:
The primary advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy is that there is a lesser chance of extension through perineum till anal sphincter. But it is more difficult to repair, and there is an increased risk of blood loss and it shows a less reliable healing.

Characteristic Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair Easy More difficult
Healing Better Not as good
Post-op Pain Less More
Anatomical Results Excellent Not as good
Blood Loss Less More
Dyspareunia Rare Occasional
Extensions Common Uncommon

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A primigravida presented with labor pains at 38 weeks of gestation. The baby was in breech presentation and a vaginal breech delivery was planned. Identify the following maneuver performed during the delivery.
questions.solution:
The given maneuver is the modified Prague maneuver done for a chin-to-pubis delivery of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Note: If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau maneuver.

Other options:

Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to manage shoulder dystocia. It involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­screw fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder. 

In the Zavanelli maneuver, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. It is done as a third line of managing shoulder dystocia after failing to deliver the baby vaginally.

Lovset maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals Bandl’s ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring is a pathological retraction ring.

Bandl's ring/ pathological retraction ring is formed in cases of obstructed labor. The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Clinically, the patient is usually in a lot of distress. She will complain of continuous pain in the abdomen and there may be features of maternal exhaustion. It is an indication of cesarean delivery.

Note:

Constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring is formed due to incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.solution:

Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipitoanterior or posterior  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse or oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse or oblique  Transverse

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: The obstetric grip performed in the picture is used to detect ______.

choices.text: The fetal pole occupying the fundus

questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Pelvic grip (Leopold's fourth grip) and it is used to detect the degree of descent.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

Leopold Grip Importance

Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick 

To know presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head
