questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option C: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: Regarding investigations done in Rh-negative pregnancies, which of the following is false:

choices.text: Fetal MCA doppler to determine peak systolic velocity
The critical titre for indirect Coomb's test is 1:16
Paternal blood group determination is irrelevant
Fetal blood sampling is done to assess fetal anemia

questions.solution:
Paternal blood group determination is relevant.

Protocol for RH isoimmunisation is as follows 

RH negative mother: The first step determine the blood group of husband 

  • If husband blood group is negative: Routine antenatal care  is given 
  • If husband blood group is positive: ICT is done 

ICT negative: - No isoimmunisation, prevention of iso immunisation

ICT positive:- Determine the titre, 1:16 is considered as critical titre.

Titre less than 1:16 Titre more than 1:16
Monitor 2 weekly ICT and deliver @ 37 weeks

Monitor fetal anemia with middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity

unit: Multiples of median (MOM)

The critical value of MOM is 1.5 MOM 

MOM less than 1.5 MOM more than 1.5
Deliver at 37 completed weeks

Gestation >34 weeks:- Deliver

Gestation <34 weeks:- Fetal blood sampling 

 

Fetal Blood sampling 

Haematocrit (HCT) <30 : Intrauterine transfusion 

Haematocrit (HCT) >30: weekly fetal blood sampling based on middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity: Deliver at 34 completed weeks

questions.text: At term pregnancy, the normal amniotic fluid appearance is __________.
questions.solution:
At term, the amniotic fluid is cloudy and contains a large number of white flakes of vernix.

Amniotic fluid appearance is determined by the proportion of cloudiness and the number of flakes released from the fetal skin over the period of pregnancy. This is summated by the amniotic fluid macroscore.

At the end of the 32 nd week of pregnancy, the amniotic fluid is clear and does not have any flakes (Option C). By the 36 th week, the amniotic fluid starts to have some flakes (Option A) and gradually we will begin to see traces of cloudiness also. By 42 nd week.i.e. term of pregnancy, the amniotic fluid has a large number of flakes and is very cloudy (Option D).

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

Related Pearl: Change in the amniotic fluid volume through gestation

Period of gestation   Amniotic fluid volume
10 weeks 10-20 mL
16 weeks 250 mL
33 weeks 800 mL
38-39 weeks plateaus at 1000 mL
40 weeks  800

Note: The average volume increases with gestational age, peaking at 800-1000 mL, which coincides with 36-37 weeks' gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding amniocentesis?

choices.text: Traditional  amniocentesis is performed at 16-20 weeks
Traditional amniocentesis is difficult to do compared to early amniocentesis
Early amniocentesis is performed at 11-14 weeks
Less fluid is drawn in early amniocentesis compared to traditional amniocentesis

questions.solution:
Early amniocentesis (done at 11-14 wks) is more challenging than traditional amniocentesis because the amnion fuses with adjacent chorion only by 16 weeks of gestation, making the sac puncture more difficult.

Amniocentesis is performed using aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle.

The needle is directed into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure.

Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping and chromosomal microarray analysis.

Amniocentesis

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

16-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks

(associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

(less fluid is drawn - approximately 1 ml for each week of gestation)

Indications

a) Diagnostic

Sex-linked disorders/Karyotyping/Inborn errors of metabolism/Neural tube defects

b) Therapeutic

Abortion induction, decompression of uterus in acute hydramnios, amnioinfusion in oligohydramnios
Complication

Chorioamnionitis

Premature Rupture Of Membranes (PROM)

Fetal trauma/loss

Fetomaternal haemorrhage

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. Ultrasonographic examination shows overlapping of skull bones and no fetal movements. Which of the following is false about this likely condition?

choices.text: Robert's sign may be seen as early as 12 hours
Spalding's sign may be seen on USG
Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required
Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intrauterine fetal death (absent fetal heart sounds, no fetal movements and Spalding's sign on ultrasound). The false statement is spontaneous expulsion is rare and induction is required.

It is an antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. In most of these cases, spontaneous expulsion occurs within 10-14 days. 

The causes of intrauterine fetal death are given below -

  • Maternal - Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, diabetes in pregnancy, maternal infections, APLA, hyperpyrexia, thrombophilias, abnormal labour, post-term pregnancy, SLE
  • Fetal - Chromosomal abnormalities, structural abnormalities, infections, Rh-incompatibility, non-immune hydrops, growth restriction
  • Placental - Antepartum hemorrhage, cord accident, twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency
  • Iatrogenic - External cephalic version, drugs
  • Idiopathic 

Sonographically, fetal heartbeat and fetal movements are absent. Overlapping of skull bones irregularly on one another known as Spalding's sign can be seen. Also, a gas shadow in the chambers of the fetal heart and great vessels called Robert's sign is seen as early as 12 hours.

Complications like infection following rupture of membranes with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii, and blood coagulation disorders may occur.

Management includes early intervention for psychological issues, signs of uterine infection, prolonged retention beyond two weeks, and falling fibrinogen levels. The first-line choice for induction of labor in such cases is a combination of mifepristone and prostaglandins, although misoprostol and oxytocin infusion can also be utilised effectively.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text:
The suture application shown in the given image will be most useful in the management of which of the following conditions?

(PPH- Postpartum hemorrhage)

choices.text: PPH caused due to  HELLP syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a B-lynch suture. It is most useful in the management of PPH caused due to polyhydramnios.

It is a technique to control severe atonic postpartum hemorrhage, which can occur as a result of polyhydramnios. B-lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which oppose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

Predisposing factors for PPH are:

  • Atonic PPH:
    • Grand multipara
    • Previous history of PPH
    • Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia
    • Precipitate labor, prolonged labor
    • Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
    • Labor induction or augmentation with oxytocin
    • Placental anomalies: Placenta previa/ accreta/ increta/ percreta/ abruptio placenta
  • Traumatic PPH:
    • Instrumental deliveries
    • Episiotomy
  • PPH due to Coagulopathy:
    • Sepsis
    • IUD
    • HELLP syndrome

For PPH due to Coagulopathy - transfusion of blood products such as Fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, platelet concenterate is given.

questions.text: What is the period after fertilization during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins?
questions.solution:
The period after fertilization, during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins, is >13 days.

The proposed mechanisms are:

  • Incomplete splitting of one embryo into two 
  • Fusion of a portion of one embryo from a monozygotic pair onto the other. 

Types of monozygotic twinning:

Time of division after fertilization                        Type of twin                    
0 - 4 days (morula)    Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA)
4 - 8 days (blastocyst)    Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
8 - 12 days (implanted blastocyst)    Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days (formed embryonic disc)    Conjoined twins

Related Pearl: Twinning
